resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: Basin. Basins from the thirteenth or fourteenth century were imported from Iran, Irak or Syria for collectors and amateurs of "Oriental" art. Basin, 14th century, metal, Iran (France, Louvre Museum). From the personal collection of Raymond Koechlin.
resource.chars:
Basin. Basins from the thirteenth or fourteenth century were imported from Iran, Irak or Syria for collectors and amateurs of "Oriental" art.

Basin, 14th century, metal, Iran (France, Louvre Museum). From the personal collection of Raymond Koechlin.

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: Chinese screen representing a mountain landscape. Screens were imported from China and Japan in the eighteenth and nineteenth century, and were sold by Asian art sellers to collectors.

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: Jean-Jules-Antoine Lecomte de Nouÿ (1842–1923) was a French Orientalist painter: his work was deeply influenced by travels he made to Greece, Egypt and Turkey, but also by the teachings of Orientalist painter Jean-Léon Gérôme. His work participated to the establishment of the Oriental fantasy in France. He used his travels as inspiration for his paintings, which represented a hazy, dreamy, fictional Middle East filled with harems and drugs. His studio was the reflection of the mind of an artist who found creative inspiration in the faraway fantasy of Orient: filled with objects he bought during his travels or from merchants in Paris, Lecomte de Nouÿ worked and taught to his students in a space where he could find visual inspiration for his Oriental scenes. Jean-Jules-Antoine Lecomte de Nouÿ, Self-portrait, 1887, oil on canvas (France, Grenoble Museum).
resource.chars:
Jean-Jules-Antoine Lecomte de Nouÿ (1842–1923) was a French Orientalist painter: his work was deeply influenced by travels he made to Greece, Egypt and Turkey, but also by the teachings of Orientalist painter Jean-Léon Gérôme. His work participated to the establishment of the Oriental fantasy in France. He used his travels as inspiration for his paintings, which represented a hazy, dreamy, fictional Middle East filled with harems and drugs.

His studio was the reflection of the mind of an artist who found creative inspiration in the faraway fantasy of Orient: filled with objects he bought during his travels or from merchants in Paris, Lecomte de Nouÿ worked and taught to his students in a space where he could find visual inspiration for his Oriental scenes.

Jean-Jules-Antoine Lecomte de Nouÿ, Self-portrait, 1887, oil on canvas (France, Grenoble Museum).

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: Mosque lamp. In enamelled glass or in hammered metal, those luxury objects were initially destined to be hanged in mosque or mausoleum in Egypt or Syria. Often from the thirteenth or the fourteenth century, mosque lamps were during the nineteenth century collected by rich amateurs of Islamic art. Mosque lamp, c. 1310, enamelled glass (France, Museum of Decorative Arts). From the personal collection of Albert Goupil.
resource.chars:
Mosque lamp. In enamelled glass or in hammered metal, those luxury objects were initially destined to be hanged in mosque or mausoleum in Egypt or Syria. Often from the thirteenth or the fourteenth century, mosque lamps were during the nineteenth century collected by rich amateurs of Islamic art.

Mosque lamp, c. 1310, enamelled glass (France, Museum of Decorative Arts). From the personal collection of Albert Goupil.
